awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Conference: NSF Summer School on Computational Modeling of Disordered Materials for Historically Black Colleges and Universities
awd_abstract_narration:
SUMMARY

This award supports an intensive training workshop for students and faculty members from Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) and Minority Serving Institutions (MSI) on computational modeling of complex materials, with an emphasis on the fundamental concepts of physics, chemistry and materials science. The participants will learn and employ a variety of modern structural modeling techniques and widely used computer simulation methodologies to understand and analyze the properties of highly complex and technologically important disordered materials. The workshop will adopt a lecture-laboratory approach, whereby each lecture is followed by hands-on computational "laboratory" exercises, aimed at illustrating how information from the lecture can be directly employed for practical simulations of complex materials. The topics to be addressed in the laboratory exercises are: structural modeling techniques on the length scale of atoms, analyses of structural properties, geometry optimization, electronic and vibrational properties, as well as thermodynamic properties of different types of disordered materials. The participants will also be introduced to the fundamentals of emerging data-centric and machine-learning techniques in materials modeling. The workshop will: (i) expose students to a wide range of state-of-the-art computer simulation techniques, and the applications of these techniques to real-world problems; (ii) bridge the gap between the standard teaching curriculum at the undergraduate and graduate levels and the actual expertise and knowledge that are needed for practicing computational materials science even at its basic level; (iii) develop collaborative initiatives between HBCUs and state-funded and private universities to initiate research in computational modeling of complex materials. The PIs will provide post-workshop support for a period of six months so that participants may develop small publishable research projects on their return to their home institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU), along with other minority-serving institutions (MSI), play a vital role in the education and development of under-represented minorities. The educational success of all students, including African American and minority students, is crucially important not only to meet the growing need of STEM-capable workforce for the US economy in the 21st century but also to establish a balanced and fair society in our country. Engaging students from HBCUs and MSIs to Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines has been one of the major challenges in tertiary or postsecondary education in the USA.

The main objective of the workshop was to raise awareness among minority students from HBCUs about the importance of studying STEM degrees at the undergraduate and graduate levels and to highlight the opportunities that are available to STEM graduates in research, education and technology sectors, upon successful completion of a STEM degree. The workshop not only exposed students and faculty members from HBCUs to some of the modern techniques and practices in computational modeling of materials, but also ignited their general interest in computational sciences by motivating them to pursue STEM degrees at the graduate level and beyond.

The key outcomes of the workshop were as follows:

(i) The workshop resulted in the training of a selected number of undergraduate/graduate students and faculty members from HBCUs and minority-serving institutions in computational modeling of materials.

(ii) For undergraduate students, participation and successful completion of a capstone project significantly improved their readiness for Graduate Programs in Computational Science, whereas Graduate students working on materials modeling and related areas found the workshop particularly benefitting for their research.

(iii) The workshop provided the opportunity for joint research collaborations between HBCUs and non-HBCU institutions within the framework of NSF’s HBCU Excellence in Research program; the collaborations rely on exchange visitor programs (EVP). The EVP will initiate the primary interaction and co-operation between the collaborating institutions to conduct preliminary studies that are needed for launching a full-scale collaborative research project under the NSF HBCU Excellence in Research program.
